On Friday, May 8th, families of the Dunkirk City School Pre-K program were invited to pick up instructional packets at the Middle School. Program director, Mr. Kisun Peters, proudly helped some of the School #7 teachers hand out "goodie bags" full of learning tools and games.

Items such as paints, play dough, paper, markers, and glue were sent home as part of a grant partnership with the Quality Stars program.

Student packets also included several hands-on fun activities such as pizza making, planting seeds, and sensory fidgets. It is the goal of the program and educators to provide appropriate and engaging activities for learning while at home.

The entire program would like to thank the families for their continued participation and communication during these times. For those families who were not able to come out for the distribution, packets will be delivered next week to each of the residences.

Please be on the lookout for the delivered materials.

The Dunkirk City School District is a partner with the Chautauqua County Health Network as part of the Creating Healthy Schools and Communities grant. One of the initiatives we were going to begin this spring is the Daily Mile program. As a part of this program, teachers take their students outside for 15 minutes a day (in addition to their regularly scheduled PE classes) and students run/jog/walk on a safe path. We encourage you to do this at home (please remember responsible social distancing) and to use the link below so we can keep track of your progress. You can click on this link each Friday, find the current week and check the boxes of the days you completed the Daily Mile. Research shows that when students participate in the Daily Mile, there is a positive impact on their academics as well as behavior. Questions can be directed to School Wellness Coordinator, Mike Green at mgreen@dunkirkcsd.org.
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1U1VoXfrAgZPDbe7jAnNslgfis4tD8W8HJSO12wiUyr4/edit

Middle School/High School Tip of the Day!
Suggest that your teen print out a blank U.S. map, then look up today’s weather for states in different parts of the country. Your child can record the data on the map and in the process, build research skills, get a geography lesson, and see weather patterns.

Sugiera a su hijo imprimir un mapa en blanco de EE. UU. y buscar el clima del día para los estados en distintas partes del país. Él puede registrar ahí los datos y también desarrollar competencias de investigación, asimilar una lección de geografía y ver patrones climáticos.

An acronym is a word made of initials, such as NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration). Let each family member pick a newspaper page and circle the acronyms. Take turns reading your acronyms aloud—can others figure out what the letters stand for?

Elementary Tip of the Day!
Play this place value game with your child. Take turns secretly writing a three-digit number, such as 385. The other person asks questions to figure out the number—using the terms “hundreds,” “tens,” and “ones.” (“Is the number in the hundreds place greater than 5?”)

Con su hijo, jueguen con valores posicionales y túrnense escribiendo en secreto un número de tres dígitos, como 385. El otro hace preguntas para descifrar el número usando los términos “centenas”, “decenas” y “unidades”. (“¿Es el número del lugar de las centenas mayor que 5?”).

Middle School/High School Tip of the Day!
Help your teen understand the difference between having friends and being popular. Ask “What makes a good friend?” and “How should friends treat each other?” Your discussion may lead your child to realize that true friendship is more important that popularity.

Elementary Tip of the Day!
If your child faces a problem, like a disagreement with a friend, it may be tempting to offer advice right away. Instead, try talking through the situation to help your youngster come up with a solution. Example: “What could you say to your friend that might help?”

A portfolio of schoolwork can be a great motivator. Let your child get a binder, add one or two graded assignments to it every week, and include a note about why each piece is special. Celebrate the end of each grading period by looking through the portfolio together.

Use doodles to stir up your child’s creativity. Start with a theme, like dogs, cars, or food. Each person draws a random line or squiggle on paper. Then, trade papers and use your imaginations to incorporate the line into a drawing that fits the theme.

Let your teen see your curiosity. For example, if you want to know the exchange rate between dollars and Euros, let your child see you look it up. You’ll encourage your teen to do the same and show that learning is a lifelong process.

Middle School/High School Tip of the Day!
Teens often lash out at parents with rudeness. A calm response from you can keep things from escalating. You might say, “I understand you’re upset. We’ll finish talking when you calm down.” Or “I want to hear your thoughts, but you’ll need to show some respect.”

Los adolescentes con frecuencia atacan a los padres duramente. Si responde con tranquilidad, puede evitar que la situación empeore. Puede decir “sé que estás enojado; seguiremos hablando cuando estés tranquilo”, o “quiero saber qué piensas, pero debes hablar con respeto”.

You’ll get better results and fewer arguments if you ask, rather than tell, your youngster what to do. For example, if your child’s backpack is on the floor (again!), try, “Where does your backpack belong?” instead of “Put your backpack in the closet.”

Teach your teen the “Grandma Test.” Before posting on social media, ask, “Would I want grandma to see this?” If the answer is no, your child should reconsider. Remember, future college picks and employers will likely want to see what your teen has posted online.

Elementary Tip of the Day!
Show your child capillary action (how water moves through plants). Place a cut stalk of celery in a glass with 1/4 cup water and a few drops of dark food coloring. Wait a few hours. Then, your youngster will see the color showing where the water traveled up the stalk.

Muéstrele a su hijo el efecto capilar (cómo pasa el agua por las plantas). Ponga un tallo de apio cortado en un vaso con 1/4 de agua y unas gotas de colorante alimenticio oscuro. Espere unas horas. Luego, su hijo verá cómo aparece el color por donde pasó el agua en el tallo.

Here’s a way to boost your child’s creative thinking. Take turns secretly picking a topic (say, building a snowman) and placing a sticky note on several related objects (hat, mitten, carrot). Then, look for the clues and solve each other’s mysteries.

Suggest that your child replace forms of the verb “to be” (“is,” “am,” “are,” “was”) with snappier verbs to liven up writing assignments. Instead of “Alex is happy,” your child could write “Alex’s joy bubbled over,” for example.

Elementary Tip of the Day!
How many things in your house are taller than your child? Shorter? Together, measure a piece of yarn or string that matches your youngster’s height. Your child can use the string to “measure” items around the house and find out.

Here’s an observation and memory builder. Have your child study your surroundings for two minutes. Then, while your youngster’s eyes are closed, change one thing. You might reposition a lamp, or take off your shoes, for example. Can your child spot the change?

Esta actividad es para desarrollar la observación y la memoria. Haga que su hijo estudie el entorno por dos minutos. Luego, mientras tiene los ojos cerrados, cambie una cosa. Por ejemplo, puede cambiar de posición una lámpara o sacarse los zapatos. ¿Su hijo detecta el cambio?
